title: Refers to data
description: Refer to the data directly，give the data type or changes in data(trend)
ExampleTxt: Daily Covid cases surge 60% in a week to 61,900 in biggest rise since Freedom Day as admissions climb by a quarter and deaths creep up 9%

title: States an issue
description: Gives a broad overview by stating the topic or the issue(fact or study).Not give the data directly
ExampleTxt: Elections 2022: live council results for England, Scotland and Wales

title: Makes a judgment
description: Makes a judgment on the data or the issue at hand
ExampleTxt: Digital banks beat the high street on customer service

title: Ask a question
description: Use the question as the title directly
ExampleTxt: Does Gen Z spend too much time on social media?

title: Include emotional appeal
description: Presents the information using an emotional angle, like  through the use of adjectives (on the data or the fact)
ExampleTxt: Boris Johnson’s tumultuous three years as prime minister – in charts

title: Give the link
description: Give the relevant database link directly then people can click to enter
ExampleTxt: Data from Effis shows that as of 23 July, just over 515,000 hectares (1.27m acres) of land had been burned across EU countries...

title: Mention the data source name only
description: Cite the name of the institute/data report/website without giving a link
ExampleTxt: The NHS has succeeded in eliminating two-year waits, but in future the length of delays in treatment looks set to creep up again.

title: News about the inverted pyramid
description: In journalism, the inverted pyramid refers to a story structure where the most important information (or what might even be considered the conclusion) is presented first.The who, what, when, where and why appear at the start of a story, followed by supporting details and background information.
ExampleTxt: Boris Johnson has resigned as Conservative leader after nearly three years in Downing Street. After taking the helm in July 2019 following Theresa May’s resignation, Johnson secured a large Conservative majority in parliament after calling a snap general election in December that year...

title: Basic description
description: Only a rough summary of the content， describing the real news event
ExampleTxt: As the final votes are counted, heavy Conservative losses are tempered by a mixed picture for Labour while Lib Dems and the Greens perform well. The SNP continues to dominate in Scotland and Plaid Cymru gain seats in their heartlands and beyond.

title: Dill down
description: Guide the reader to focus on a specific area from a large overall image, and highlight local problems through a holistic local approach.
ExampleTxt: When Covid-19 hit Georgia in March 2020, the Atlanta Breakfast Club closed its doors to in-person dining for weeks on end...general managers and other staff at a time of fierce competition for workers in one of the tightest labour markets in the US.

title: Compare difference/proportion
description: Show the influence of a factor by comparing different data
ExampleTxt: This is lowest among the over-70s: only 6% of those aged 70-79 in England have not had both doses. However, for 50- to 54-year-olds, who have been eligible for vaccines since mid-March, the number not fully vaccinated stands at 19%.

title: Changing over time
description: Compare the changes of some data under the effect of time, and summarize the trend of things.
ExampleTxt: Initially, reinfections with coronavirus were rare. But as the Omicron variant arrived at the end of 2021, and immunity from previous infections waned, reinfections increased to take up a greater proportion of overall infections.

title: Emotional appeal
description: Empathy engages us with the story content: we pay attention, and we perceive and reflect on the message.
ExampleTxt: He died the following month, aged 89. 'My nan was too afraid to go to the hospital, as he was put in a Covid ward. His death certificate stated Covid on it as well as heart failure and the UTI. He was a very poorly man. He didn’t need any extra oxygen while he had Covid, but it may not have helped his heart, which eventually gave out.'

title: Emphasize value/extreme/outlier
description: Highlight an abnormal value to highlight problems or contrast， and attempts to explain why this is happening or resulting in consequences.
ExampleTxt: In 2016, global temperatures were 1.05C higher than this average – a record in the data that runs to 1850. The 13 hottest global temperatures in the data have all occurred since 2000.

title: Co-relation
description: Describe the correlation/causality between different data.
ExampleTxt: Most classical measures of social capital, such as civic engagement and intra-class bonding, were not correlated with improved life outcomes, the researchers found. However, one measure looked especially important. “Economic connectedness”—the extent of friendships across social classes—was strongly associated with increased rates of high-school completion, reduced rates of teenage pregnancy and increased income for those born poorer.

title: Dissect the fact
description: Journalists investigate the relationship between different factors of a story.
ExampleTxt: Higher interest rates have also raised the chances of a recession in some countries, with economists fearing a return to the stagflation of the 1970s — a situation characterised by persistent price pressures and weak growth…Another point of concern is asset prices, especially for houses.

title: Cite the authority
description: Quote authoritative people's words/government and other authoritative reports to assist in data explanation.
ExampleTxt: Authorities should wait until more people are vaccinated before lifting public health restrictions, says Christina Pagel, director of UCL’s Clinical Operational Research Unit, said There is no disadvantage to more people being vaccinated..

title: Opposite point of view
description: On the basis of quoting a point of view, add the opposite point of view to illustrate the event from different perspectives.
ExampleTxt: Others, however, back the government’s decision to unlock now. “This virus is not going away,” says Paul Hunter, professor in medicine at the University of East Anglia.

title: Predict
description: Based on the existing data, predict the future development direction of the event
ExampleTxt: This includes economists’ expectations for the future, which show inflation projections being steadily revised up for 2023, according to leading forecasters polled by Consensus Economics.

title: Method
description: Provide methods for data calculation/collection.
ExampleTxt: To fill in these voids in our understanding of the pandemic, The Economist has built a machine-learning model, which estimates excess deaths for every country on every day since the pandemic began.

title: Refers to data
description: refer to the data directly，give the data type or changes in data(trend)
ExampleTxt: While three in four people in rich countries are vaccinated against Covid, just over one in seven is in poor countries

title: States an issue
description: Gives a broad overview by stating the topic or the issue(fact or study).Not give the data directly
ExampleTxt: UK: people in the hospital with coronavirus each day

title: Makes a judgment
description: Makes a judgment on the data or the issue at hand
ExampleTxt: The big wait

title: Ask a question
description: Presents the information using an emotional angle, like  through the use of adjectives (on the data or the fact)
ExampleTxt: Who-is and isn’t vaccinated?

title: Data sources
description: Specify the data source or give a link to the data source.
ExampleTxt: Data：data.gov.uk

title: Visualization source/ producer
description: Describe source of visualization.
ExampleTxt: Guardian Graphic

title: Description visualization
description: Describe the specific trend of visualization and summarize data events.
ExampleTxt: NHS England waiting list for treatment. The NHS is prioritizing very long waits, yet the overall list continues to grow

title: Supplement additional information/details
description: Add other information, such as information not clearly shown in the chart, or add details for a certain data, to further supplement the chart
ExampleTxt: Note: Time periods of BA.4 and BA.5 becoming dominant are estimates.

title: Explain visual encoding
description: Visual coding method, such as specific sampling method, data selection event segment, etc.
ExampleTxt: Note: Charts show 14-day case averages, and the frequency of variants among cases is an estimate. Sequencing rates can reflect localized trends based on testing from a particular region or hospital. Charts show the latest available data, which may be lagged and may change as additional sequences are completed. Recent data is based on the smallest samples and is especially likely to change.

title: Individual data points
description: Focusing on individual data points and placed adjacent to the data.

title: Summarize trends / high-level messages
description: A text annotation within the plot area may provide additional context about the data or help orient the viewer by explaining the choice of scale or range.
ExampleTxt: UK：More than 40 houses destroyed in London after grass fires spread in several areas

title: Add another chart
description: Add auxiliary charts in the annotation for supplementary explanation/explanation.

title: Line chart
description: A line chart (aka line plot, line graph) uses points connected by line segments from left to right to demonstrate changes in value. The standard way to show a changing time series.
ExampleTxt: In the past decade, there has been record...

title: Bar chart
description: A bar chart or bar graph is a chart or graph that presents categorical data with rectangular bars with heights or lengths proportional to the values that they represent.Columns work well for showing change over time - but usually best with only one series of data at a time.
ExampleTxt: Who is-and isn't-vaccinated

title: Map
description: A diagram or collection of data showing the spatial distribution of something or the relative positions of its components.
ExampleTxt: US covid map

title: Table
description: A table chart is a means of arranging data in rows and columns.
ExampleTxt: Oxfam ranking 2017

title: Scatter plot
description: The standard way to show the relationship between two continuous variables, each of which has its own axis.
ExampleTxt: Wealthy countries have vaccinated far more people against Covid than poorer ones

title: Bubble
description: Like a scatterplot, but adds additional detail by sizing the circles according to a third variable.
ExampleTxt: Friendship across class lines may boost social mobility and decrease poverty

title: Stacked chart
description: This type of graph (sometimes called a stream graph) depicts aggregate patterns and often supports drill-down into a subset of individual series.
ExampleTxt: Europe and Americans have record the most cases throughout the pandamic

title: Dumbell chart/Slope
description: Perfect for showing how ranks have changed over time or vary between categories.
ExampleTxt: More people are living without sex

title: Treemap
description: Treemap visualizations are space-efficient displays of large structured datasets: contiguous shapes are organized according to their hierarchy or categorization.Use for hierarchical part-to-whole relationships
ExampleTxt: Who Has The Most Historical Responsibility for Climate Change?

title: Small multiple
description: A small multiple is a data visualization that consists of multiple charts arranged in a grid. This makes it easy to compare the entirety of the data. They are also known as trellis, lattice, grid, and panel charts.
ExampleTxt: Weekly death rates, US

title: Other
description: Other types of visualization, such as Sankey diagram, thermal diagram, etc., and specially drawn information diagram
ExampleTxt: Excess death by countries

title: Inspect
description: Show the specifics of the data to get details on demand
ExampleTxt: hover or click an element to see a tooltip with more information

title: Connect
description: show me related items
ExampleTxt: Click on one element and highlight all similar elements for comparison

title: Select
description: Mark something as interesting
ExampleTxt: Highlight elements to keep track of it in an animated graph

title: Filter
description: Show me something conditionally
ExampleTxt: By checking a box to only display results that are over/under a certain threshold, or selecting one country from a drop-down menu

title: Abstract/elaborate
description: Show me more or less detail
ExampleTxt: Zoom in or out inside a map view to adjust the level of abstraction

title: Explore
description: Show me something else
ExampleTxt: Show specifics based on the user’s input/ query

title: Narrate
description: Show a different section
ExampleTxt: Click on a stepper button to be guided to the next part of the story
